ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata: Sorts character variables using the ASCII collating sequence.
Sorts characters according to the Danish and Norwegian convention.
Sorts character variables using the EBCDIC collating sequence.
Sorts characters according to the Polish convention.
Sorts characters according to the Finnish and Swedish convention.

Sorts character variables using an alternate collating sequence, as defined by your installation, 
to reflect a country's National Use Differences.

[Syntax: SORTSEQ= collating-sequence] 
      
Specifies the collating sequence. The collating-sequence can be a collating-sequence-option, 
a translation table, an encoding, or the keyword LINGUISTIC.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip11: Specifies linguistic collation, which sorts characters according to rules of the specified language.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: DATA= SAS-data-set] 
      
Identifies the input SAS data set.

Copies the SAS internal date and time when the SAS data set was created and the 
date and time when it was last modified before the sort to the resulting sorted 
data set. Note that the operating environment date and time are not preserved.

[Syntax: DUPOUT=SAS-data-set] 
      
Specifies the output data set to which duplicate observations are written.

Maintains the relative order of the observations within the input data set in the 
output data set.

Does not necessarily maintain the relative order of the observations within the input data set in the 
output data set.
Sorts and replaces an indexed data set when the OUT= option is not specified.
Checks for and eliminates observations with duplicate BY values.

Checks for and eliminates duplicate observations.
      
Note: This option has been removed from the SAS 9.4 documentation. Consider using the NODUPKEY option instead.

[Syntax: OUT=SAS-data-set] 
      
Names the output data set. If SAS-data-set does not exist, then PROC SORT creates it.

Enables the input data set to be deleted before the replacement output data set 
is populated with observations.

Before sorting, checks within the input data set to determine whether the sequence 
of observations are in order.

Sorts character variables using a collating sequence that is reversed from the normal 
collating sequence.
Specifies the maximum amount of memory that is available to PROC SORT.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies the amount of memory in bytes, where n is a real number.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies the amount of memory in kilobytes, where n is a real number.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies the amount of memory in megabytes, where n is a real number
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies the amount of memory in gigabytes, where n is a real number.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies that all available memory can be used.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata: Stores only the BY variables and the observation numbers in temporary files.
Enables the activation of multi-threaded sorting.
Prevents the activation of multi-threaded sorting.

Checks for and eliminates observations from the output data set that have a unique 
sort key. A sort key is unique when the observation containing the key is the only 
observation within a BY group. An observation has a unique sort key when it is the 
only observation within a BY group.

Note: Unlike NODUPKEY, which writes one observation of a BY group to the output data 
set and discards all other observations from the BY group, the NOUNIQUEKEY maintains 
BY group integrity. Either all observations of a BY group are written to the output 
data set when the BY group consists of two or more observations, or all observations 
of the BY group are discarded when the BY group consists of a single observation. 
 
Interactions:If the NOUNIQUEREC and NOUNIQUEKEY options are specified then NOUNIQUEREC 
will be ignored and processing will proceed as if only NOUNIQUEKEY had been specified. 

The NODUP category (NODUPKEY, NODUPREC) of options and the NOUNIQUE category of options 
(NOUNIQUEREC, NOUNIQUEKEY) are not compatible. If any of the NODUP category of options 
and the NOUNIQUE category of options are specified together, an error will be printed 
to the SAS log. 

Tip:The UNIQUEOUT= option can be used only with the NOUNIQUEKEY or NOUNIQUEREC options. 
It cannot be combined with either the NODUPREC or NODUPKEY option.

Checks for and eliminates observations from the output data set that are adjacently 
unique. PROC SORT only writes to the output data set observations that it determines 
are not unique. For example, during output, observation B is compared to observation 
A that precedes it and then to observation C that follows it. If observation B has 
variable values that differ from observation A’s or observation C’s variable values, 
then observation B is considered unique and is not written to the output data set.
When the UNIQUEOUT= option is specified with NOUNIQUEREC, then unique observations 
are written to the data set specified by the UNIQUEOUT= option. 

Note: The NOUNIQUEREC option might not function as expected. Only observations that 
PROC SORT determines are unique are eliminated from the output data set. Because 
observations within a BY group can be arranged in any order, equivalent observations 
are not guaranteed to be grouped together. Therefore, an observation determined to 
be unique from other adjacent observations might not be truly unique within the BY 
group. To eliminate only observations that are truly unique within all BY groups in 
the output data set, consider using the NOUNIQEKEY option when sorting BY all variables. 
The NOUNIQUEREC option is analogous to the NODUPREC option. Use these two options with 
caution. 
 
Interactions:If the NOUNIQUEREC and NOUNIQUEKEY options are both specified, the 
NOUNIQUEREC option will be ignored and processing will proceed as if only NOUNIQUEKEY 
had been specified. 

The NODUP category (NODUPKEY, NODUPREC) of options and the NOUNIQUE category of 
options (NOUNIQUEREC, NOUNIQUEKEY) not compatible. If any of the NODUP category 
of options and the NOUNIQUE category of options are specified together, an error 
will be printed to the SAS log. 

Tip:The UNIQUEOUT= option can be used only with the NOUNIQUEKEY or NOUNIQUEREC 
options. It cannot be combined with either the NODUPREC or NODUPKEY option.

Syntax: UNIQUEOUT= SAS-data-set 

Specifies the output data set for observations eliminated by the NOUNIQUEREC 
and NOUNIQUEKEY options.
 
Interaction:The DUPOUT= and UNIOUT= options are not compatible and cannot be 
specified simultaneously. 

Tip:The UNIQUEOUT= option can be used only with the NOUNIQUEKEY or NOUNIQUEREC 
options. It cannot be combined with either the NODUPREC or NODUPKEY option.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: BY <DESCENDING> variable-1 <...<DESCENDING> variable-n>; 
      
Specifies the sorting variables.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that 
immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: KEY variable(s) </ option> ; 
      
Specifies sorting keys and variables.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Sorts in ascending order the variable or variables that it follows.

Reverses the sort order for the variable that it follows in the statement so that 
observations are sorted from the largest value to the smallest value. The 
DESCENDING keyword modifies all the variables that it precede on the KEY 
statement.
